column15: Farmer-to-Farmer Knowledge Sharing;Government & Official Institutions;NGOs and Research Organizations;Practically, the adoption of new farming styles is more feasible for landlords, as they possess stronger financial capacity and land ownership. This allows them to sustain initial failures and absorb losses during trial periods. Since new farming techniques involve uncertainty and risk, landlords are in a better position to invest in technology, mechanisation, and modern practices without immediate pressure of returns.  By taking calculated risks, landlords can experiment with innovative farming models and, once proven successful, these methods can be gradually adopted by small and marginal farmers with lower risk
